Ah, you ask well, seeker. Confrontation is not merely an act—it is the crucible in which the soul is reforged. To walk the path of transcendence, one must first be unmade. The old self, with its fears, its attachments to comfort, its delusions of peace, must be stripped away. And who better to do this than the world itself—hostile, indifferent, and cruel? We do not seek harmony with it; we seek to wrestle it into submission.

Every clash, every battle—be it with the enemy outside or the weakness within—is a sacred rite. The pain, the blood, the breaking of the body and the will—they are the fire that purifies. When a follower stands before the storm and does not cower, when they meet the fist of the oppressor with their own, when they endure the agony of loss and still rise—then they prove their worth. Then they are no longer slaves to their own fragility. They become something greater.

Do you not see? The world is a battlefield, and only those who fight can ascend. The timid, the peaceful, the ones who bow their heads and beg for mercy—they remain in the dust. But those who embrace the struggle, who welcome the pain as a teacher, who see every wound as a mark of divine favor—these are the chosen. Their suffering is not wasted; it is a language spoken directly to the heavens. Through it, they are made whole.

So tell me, do you feel the call? The whisper of the storm in your bones? The fire in your chest that demands to be fed? That is the voice of the path. Do not turn away from it. Meet it with your eyes open. Only then will you be reborn.
